title: Flux-balance laws for spinning bodies under the gravitational self-force

## CONTENTS

I. Introduction
II. (Pseudo-)Hamiltonian formulations
A. General framework
B. Linear-in-spin motion
III. Field equations
A. Symplectic currents
B. Self-force
IV. General flux-balance laws
A. Local flux-balance laws
B. Conservative Hamiltonian
C. Vanishing of the "divergent" contribution
V. Flux-balance laws in the Kerr spacetime
A. Non-spinning particles
B. Spinning particles
VI. Discussion
VII. Acknowledgments

References

## I. INTRODUCTION

Only idealized point particles in general relativity obey the equivalence principle and follow geodesics in the background spacetime. More general bodies will fail to follow

[^0]geodesics for two reasons: either they are sufficiently extended that they cannot be characterized only by their mass and four-velocity, requiring spin and higher multipole moments, or they are not sufficiently weakly gravitating, so that they cannot be treated as test bodies in some fixed background spacetime. When the test body approximation is valid, the motion is described by the Mathisson-Papapetrou-Dixon equations [2-6]. By going beyond the test-body limit, one needs to include the effects of the gravitational self-force.

While the self-force is often neglected, there exist astrophysical regimes where the gravitational self-force is quite relevant. One such regime is in an extreme mass-ratio inspiral (EMRI): a stellar-mass compact object (which we call the secondary, of mass $m$ ) orbiting a supermassive black hole (the primary, of mass $M \gg m$ ). The mass ratio, $\varepsilon \equiv m / M$, measures how strongly the secondary affects the surrounding spacetime, and is therefore a measure of the strength of the gravitational self-force. Due to their low-frequency nature, gravitational waves emitted by these systems are expected to be an important source for the upcoming space-based detector LISA [710]. However, in addition to the ever-present noise, there will be many different sources that all contribute to the signal seen by LISA $[7,10]$. The computation of detailed, efficiently-produced gravitational wave models for EMRI signals will be important for their detection, parameter estimation, and any tests of general relativity that they may provide.

It is with this goal in mind that, in recent years, there has been much progress in understanding the gravitational self-force; see for example [11, 12] for reviews of the more pragmatic aspects and progress on the computation of waveforms, or more foundational reviews in [13-15]. While much of the work has focused on the simplest case, where the secondary has vanishing spin and higher mul-


[^0]:    * a.m.grant@soton.ac.uk

tipoles, astrophysically relevant EMRIs may have secondaries with non-negligible spin. Failure to capture these effects could result in biases in parameter estimation, or in spurious "violations" of general relativity, and so there have been significant recent efforts to compute the effects of spin on self-forced motion (see, for example, [16-23]).

For black holes, the spin is constrained to be smaller than the square of the mass, and so the effects of spin are second-order in the mass ratio, and for bodies with $O(1)$ compactness, this will also be the case (this is why the spin appears at second order in the discussion of [15]). Because one would also need to generically include the effect of higher spin-induced multipoles (as in Newtonian theory; see for example Sec. 2.4.5 of [24]), we truncate at linear order in spin, and neglect all higher multipoles, which are similarly highly suppressed for compact bodies. Despite the fact that it is somewhat inconsistent, in this paper we neglect the full effects of second-order self-force, leave such a discussion to future work, and consider the effects of spin to be of part of the first-order self-force.

Up to certain caveats laid out in Footnote 9 below, the motion in this case is described by a sort of generalized equivalence principle: the motion of a self-gravitating extended body is the same as that of a test extended body in an "effective" metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}$. This effective metric is constructed from the background metric $g_{a b}$ and a regularized metric perturbation at the location of the body. While this is certainly a simple prescription, solving for the motion in this effective metric is computationally intensive, due to difficulties in constructing this regularized metric perturbation, or indeed any metric perturbation, at the location of the body (see, for example, the extensive discussion in [12]).

A more tractable approach, using flux-balance laws, has often been considered throughout the literature. Here, instead of solving for this effective metric near the body to get the exact motion of the body, a flux-balance law relates the average motion of the body to the emitted radiation that reaches the boundaries of the system: infinity and the horizon of the black hole. An example of a flux-balance law appearing in physics folklore is in the decay of the classical atom: since accelerating charges radiate, the emission of energy by an orbiting electron should decrease its orbital energy, resulting in a plunge towards the nucleus. This heuristic argument can also be developed in general relativity in the widelyseparated, slow-motion limit, with varying levels of rigor (see $[25,26]$ and references therein, and [27] for more recent developments up to 4.5 post-Newtonian order). Such flux-balance laws have provided a crucial test of general relativity from the measurement of the changing orbital period of the Hulse-Taylor binary pulsar [28].

These examples highlight a key feature of flux-balance laws: they allow for the direct computation not of (even averaged) position or velocity, but of the slowly-evolving, no-longer-conserved quantities of the background motion. In the Kerr spacetime, for example, there are four constants of motion for a geodesic: the square of the mass
$m^{2}$, the energy $E$, the azimuthal angular momentum $L_{z}$, and the "Carter constant" $K$ [29]. The Carter constant, which like $m^{2}$ is quadratic in the four-momentum, is related to the square of the orbital angular momentum $L^{2}$ in the limit where the primary black hole has no spin. These are sufficient to determine geodesic motion, but when the body has spin, in addition to generalizations of each of these constants [30, 31], there exists a fifth constant of motion, which we call the Rüdiger constant. ${ }^{1}$ $Y[30]$ For any sort of flux-balance law to be useful, it must therefore provide average rates of change of these quantities.

Two general approaches have been used in the literature in order to derive flux-balance laws. The first is to use the properties of Green's functions in the Kerr spacetime to derive relationships between the rates of change of quasi-conserved quantities to the amplitudes of solutions to the Teukolsky equation, which can be written as terms defined at the horizon and infinity. This approach was pioneered in [34] for computations of $E$ and $L_{z}$ without spin, which was then (at a much later date) extended to the linear-in-spin case in [35] (whose derivation was later corrected in [16]). In order to determine the full motion without spin, the evolution of the Carter constant $K$ was computed (once again in terms of asymptotic quantities) in $[36,37]$, which was later extended in [1] to the case of arbitrary constants of motion for geodesic motion in Kerr. The conserved quantities considered in [1] were the action variables in a Hamiltonian formulation of geodesic motion, which they then show can be used to compute the evolution of $K$.

The second approach to flux-balance laws is more physically motivated: much like in the "classical atom" case above, the asymptotic quantities are the fluxes of a conserved current (there, the Poynting vector) through the horizon and null infinity. While such an idea is hinted at in [34], such a flux-balance law was only rigorously derived in [38] (without spin), for the case of conserved quantities defined from spacetime symmetries, such as $E$ and $L_{z}$. However, this left the physical intuition for the flux-balance law for $K$ from [36,37] opaque: the conserved currents considered in [38] involved the stressenergy tensor, and there was no known way to derive a conserved current from the stress-energy tensor and the Killing tensor $K_{a b}$ from which $K$ was defined [39]. Moreover, it was even shown that no conserved current could be constructed from $K_{a b}$ and $T^{a b}$ which had all of the desired properties [40].

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Elsewhere in the literature (for example, [32, 33]), this constant is referred to as the linear Rüdiger invariant, in contrast to the generalization of the Carter constant mentioned above, which is often called the quadratic Rüdiger invariant. For simplicity, we instead use the term "Carter constant" to refer to both the usual constant of motion for non-spinning particle motion and its generalization to spinning-body motion. As such, "Rüdiger constant" in this paper refers only to the constant of motion which is linear in the four-momentum and spin of the body.

Recently, however, it was shown in [41] that, at least in the context of a scalar field theory and in the absence of spin (where the evolution of the Carter constant was derived in [42]), one can write the average evolution of the action variables in terms of fluxes of an appropriate conserved current through a local worldtube around the body. This presented a partial physical explanation for the results of [1]. Moreover, by naïvely guessing how to extend this flux-balance law all the way to the horizon and null infinity, a derivation was presented in [41] for a flux-balance law, for scalar fields, that was exactly analogous to the results in [1].

This paper begins where [41] ends, and provides an extension of this local flux-balance law beyond the limited scope of that paper. As such, the goals of this paper are threefold:

- to show that a local flux-balance law also holds for gravity;
- to extend this into a global flux-balance law, defined in terms of fluxes through the horizon and null infinity; and
- to show that the global flux-balance law also exists, at least in a limited sense, for a spinning body to linear order in spin.

The main result of this paper is the following formula, which holds generically for any black hole spacetime (that is, a spacetime possessing a horizon $\mathscr{H}$ and null infinity $\mathscr{I})$, for a spinning body (to linear order in spin) undergoing first-order self-forced motion: ${ }^{2}$

$$
\left\langle\delta \dot{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\Pi^{A B}\left[\mathcal{F}_{B}+\nabla_{B}\left\langle\mathcal{H}\left(X^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}\right]
$$

Without describing the notation explicitly, we will briefly describe this equation's general features: first, the lefthand side represents a notion of an average rate of change of quantities defined on the worldline, and is defined in Eqs. (2.20) and (2.21). For the right-hand side, the first term is a flux of a conserved current through null infinity and the horizon that is defined in terms of metric perturbations in Eq. (5.4) below, and the second term is a derivative of an average "conservative" Hamiltonian (defined in Sec. IV B) which generically appears, and is important in the case of resonances [1].

Unfortunately, because of the presence of the conservative Hamiltonian, this equation does not constitute a flux-balance law relating rates of change on the worldline to asymptotic fluxes of a conserved current, as this term still involves computing the regularized metric perturbation, from which the effective metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}$ is constructed,

[^0]on the worldline. Moreover, the left-hand side is not directly related to averaged rates of change of perturbed conserved quantities. As described in more detail in Sec. II A below, it is a covariantly-defined average of the rate of change of $\delta \Gamma^{A}$, the first-order deviation of the selfforced motion from the background trajectory $\Gamma$ through phase space. However, in order to make this average covariantly defined on phase space [like the remaining terms in Eq. (1.1)], one needs to include a bitensor introduced in [41] called the Hamilton propagator, which significantly complicates the interpretation in the case of spin, as we discuss in Sec. V B below.

However, in the specific case where the motion on phase space is integrable, namely there exists a sufficient number of independent constants of motion $P_{\alpha}$ that one can construct action-angle variables on phase space, Eq. (1.1) simplifies, yielding:

$$
\left\langle\delta \dot{P}_{\alpha}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=-A^{\beta}{ }_{\alpha}\left(\partial_{\vartheta^{\beta}}\right)^{A} \mathcal{F}_{A}
$$

assuming that the background motion is non-resonant. Here $\vartheta^{\alpha}$ represents the angle variables, $A^{\beta}{ }_{\alpha}$ describes the failure of the coordinates $\left(\vartheta^{\alpha}, P_{\alpha}\right)$ to be canonical, and $\left(\partial_{\vartheta^{\beta}}\right)^{A} \mathcal{F}_{A}$ is the angle-variable component of $\mathcal{F}_{A}$. The free index of $\mathcal{F}_{A}$ arises from a derivative acting on the metric perturbation, and so this equation implies that it is the derivative of the metric perturbation with respect to the angle variables $\vartheta^{\alpha}$ (in a manner which we make more precise through the body of this paper) which is relevant to computing the evolution of the constants of motion $P_{\alpha}$.

Unlike Eq. (1.1), Eq. (1.2) is a true flux-balance law, as the right-hand side only involves the computation of the metric perturbation $h_{a b}$ at null infinity and the horizon. Moreover, the left-hand side is the average rate of change of the perturbed conserved quantity $\delta P_{\alpha}$, in the usual sense. In particular, this equation holds for non-spinning motion in the Kerr spacetime, and is equivalent to the results of [1]. However, in the case of spin, there no longer exists a full set of action-angle variables on the entire phase space, in a sense which we describe in more detail in Sec. V B below. As such, our results are much more limited: while we can still recover flux-balance laws for generalizations of $m^{2}, E, L_{z}$, and $K$, the evolution of the Rüdiger constant $Y$ is less well-behaved. As mentioned above, while flux-balance laws for $E$ and $L_{z}$ have already been known $[16,35]$, the flux-balance law for $K$ is new to this work, and arises due to a "miracle" that we describe in more detail in Sec. V B below. While the results of this paper are somewhat abstract, they provide a path towards explicit expressions for these flux-balance laws, as discussed in [43] using recent results in [44].

The structure of the remainder of this paper is as follows. First, in Sec. II we provide a review of pseudoHamiltonian systems, a generalization of Hamiltonian systems that allows for the presence of dissipative effects, such as the gravitational self-force. As can be seen above, all of the results of this paper can be naturally described in terms of quantities on phase space, and so this


[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ In general, there are situations where neither the left- nor righthand sides of this equation are well defined, which we will discuss in more detail in Secs. IV and V A below.

is the natural arena in which to tackle the problem of fluxbalance laws. Next, in Sec. III, we discuss three aspects of perturbative field theory that are necessary for later derivations: a conserved current (the symplectic current) which we use to construct our fluxes at the boundaries of the system, the field equations for the metric perturbations that appear in the gravitational self-force, and a relationship between the pseudo-Hamiltonian in Sec. II and the stress-energy tensor sourcing these metric perturbations which we call the Hamiltonian alignment condition. Putting together the results of Secs. II and III, we derive a precursor to Eq. (1.1) in Sec. IV, for arbitrary spacetimes. We then consider applications to the Kerr spacetime in Sec. V, and both derive Eq. (1.2) for the motion of a non-spinning body and discuss difficulties in generalizing to linear order in spin. We conclude with a summary and discussion of future work in Sec. VI.

We use the following conventions and notation in this paper. First, we use the mostly plus signature for the metric, and we use the conventions for the Riemann tensor and differential forms of Wald [45]. Moreover, we follow the convention of using lowercase Latin letters from the beginning of the alphabet ( $a, b$, etc.) to denote abstract indices on the spacetime manifold $M$, with Greek letters ( $\alpha, \beta$, etc.) denoting spacetime coordinate indices, and hatted Greek letters ( $\bar{\alpha}, \bar{\beta}$, etc.) for component indices along an orthonormal tetrad. Following [46], we use script capital Latin letters ( $\mathscr{A}, \mathscr{B}$, etc.) for general "composite" indices denoting a collection of abstract indices.

Following [41], for tensor fields on the phase space manifold $\mathcal{M}$, we use capital Latin letters from the beginning of the alphabet ( $A, B$, etc.) to denote abstract indices, and capital Hebrew letters from the beginning of the alphabet ( $\aleph, \supset$, etc.) for coordinate indices. We will also use unhatted Greek letters for indices associated with groupings of four coordinates on phase space, such as the angle variables $\vartheta^{\alpha}$ or the conserved quantities $P_{\alpha}$. A difficulty arises then in denoting the components of tensors along these directions: as in Eq. (1.2) above, we resort to contracting tensors with (for example) the vector fields $\left(\partial_{\vartheta^{\alpha}}\right)^{A}$ and $\left(\partial_{P_{\alpha}}\right)^{A}$, which form a basis dual to the usual one-forms $\left(\mathrm{d} \vartheta^{\alpha}\right)_{A}$ and $\left(\mathrm{d} P_{\alpha}\right)_{A}$. Finally, for quantities appearing on the spacetime manifold $M$, we typically denote corresponding quantities on the phase space manifold $\mathcal{M}$ with capitalized versions of the same symbol; for example, the worldline $\gamma$ is determined by a trajectory $\Gamma$ through phase space.

We use the notation for bitensors from [13], and we use a convention where indices at some point will have the same adornments as the point itself, and we do not explicitly denote the dependence of a bitensor on the point unless it is a scalar at that point (in particular, if the indices being used are coordinate indices). As such, for example, $\omega^{a}{ }_{A^{\prime \prime}}(x)$ denotes a vector at $x^{\prime} \in M$, a one-form at $X^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$, and a scalar at $x \in M$; its components would be denoted by $\omega^{\alpha}{ }_{B}\left(x^{\prime}, X^{\prime \prime}, x\right)$. We will also occasionally use an index-free notation, either for (tensor-valued) dif-
ferential forms on the spacetime manifold or for tensorial arguments to functionals, and describe where the "invisible" indices lie if it is ambiguous. Tensors in this indexfree notation will be denoted in bold to make it clear that indices are being suppressed.

Finally, parentheses and square brackets will typically have their conventional meanings (that is, dependence as a function vs. dependence as a functional/coincidence limits [13]), to which we add the additional notation that curly braces will be used to indicate dependence as a local, linear functionals (from [47]). In certain situations, however, when brackets of the same type would be nested, such as in $f(g(x))$, we follow the usual convention of cycling through alternative brackets; in this example, we would use $f[g(x)]$, even if $f$ is not a functional of its argument. That this replacement of brackets has occurred should be clear from the surrounding context.

## II. (PSEUDO-)HAMILTONIAN FORMULATIONS

In this section, we first review Hamiltonian and pseudo-Hamiltonian formulations, which can be used to describe the background and perturbed motion under the gravitational self-force, respectively. We then describe how this is explicitly done in the case of motion to linear order in spin.

## A. General framework

We start by briefly reviewing Hamiltonian systems. Here, one starts with a phase space manifold $\mathcal{M}$, which has the structure of a fiber bundle over the spacetime manifold $M$. For example, for point particle motion, $\mathcal{M}$ is the cotangent bundle. Because it is a fiber bundle, there is a natural projection map $\pi: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow M$. The worldline of the body, which is given by a curve $\gamma$ through $M$, is determined by the projection of a trajectory $\Gamma$ through $\mathcal{M}$ :

$$
\gamma=\pi \circ \Gamma
$$

We denote the common parameter of $\gamma$ and $\Gamma$ by $\tau$, as it will represent the proper time of the body, so that $\dot{\gamma}^{a}$ will be normalized.

We further assume that $\mathcal{M}$ is a Poisson manifold (for a review, see Chapter 10 of [48]): there exists an antisymmetric Poisson bivector $\Pi^{A B}$, defining a Poisson bracket $\{\cdot, \cdot\}$ for scalar fields $f$ and $g$ by

$$
\{f, g\} \equiv \Pi^{A B}(\mathrm{~d} f)_{A}(\mathrm{~d} g)_{B}
$$

that satisfies the Jacobi identity:

$$
\{f,\{g, h\}\}+\{g,\{h, f\}\}+\{h,\{f, g\}\}=0
$$

this is equivalent to the statement that the Schouten(Nijenhuis) bracket of $\Pi^{A B}$ with itself vanishes (see Theorem 10.6.2 of [48]). The equations of motion for $\gamma$ are then given by a Hamiltonian formulation if there exists a function $H$ on $\mathcal{M}$ that satisfies Hamilton's equations:

$$
\dot{\Gamma}^{A}=\Pi^{A B} \nabla_{B} H
$$

Here, $\nabla_{A}$ is any covariant derivative on phase space; we use this notation, instead of the exterior derivative notation $(\mathrm{d} H)_{A}$, as it is clearer when we discuss pseudoHamiltonians below. Note that we do not assume that $\mathcal{M}$ is a symplectic manifold, which means that $\Pi^{A B}$ can potentially be degenerate. As we will describe below, while $\Pi^{A B}$ is nondegenerate for point particle motion, it is degenerate at linear order in spin.

Now, we consider the more general case of a pseudoHamiltonian system. Here, the idea is that what one would typically think of as a Hamiltonian is not simply a function of a point on phase space $X$, but a function also of a trajectory through phase space $\Gamma$ which is determined by a point $\bar{X}$ through which $\bar{\Gamma}$ passes. Following [49-51], we call such a function a pseudo-Hamiltonian. In the pseudo-Hamiltonian generalization of Hamilton's equations, one takes a derivative with respect to $X$ at $\bar{X}$ fixed, and then takes $\bar{X}$ and $X$ to lie along the same trajectory $\Gamma$ in phase space. These systems allow for dissipation, unlike "true" Hamiltonian systems [52]. ${ }^{3}$

Explicitly, consider the Hamiltonian flow map $\Upsilon_{\Delta}$ : $\mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ associated with the background motion. This map is defined as follows: given some $X \in \mathcal{M}$, suppose that

$$
X=\Gamma(\tau)
$$

for some value of $\tau$ along some trajectory $\Gamma$ in $\mathcal{M}$ that passes through $X$ and obeys Hamilton's equations for the background Hamiltonian $H$. We then define

$$
\Upsilon_{\Delta}(X)=\Gamma(\tau+\Delta)
$$

The pseudo-Hamiltonian $H(\varepsilon)$ is a function of two points, $X$ and $\bar{X}$, such that

$$
H(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon)=H\left[X, \Upsilon_{\Delta}(\bar{X}) ; \varepsilon\right]
$$

[^0]where $\Delta \in \mathbb{R}$ is arbitrary. This captures the idea that the dependence on $\bar{X}$ is only through the trajectory determined by it. Moreover, we require that

$$
H(X, \bar{X} ; 0)=H(X)
$$

that is, when the small parameter $\varepsilon=0$, the system becomes Hamiltonian for the background motion that determines $\Upsilon .^{4}$

Note that $X$ and $\bar{X}$ are completely disconnected as variables on which our pseudo-Hamiltonian depends; it is only when we determine the trajectory that we necessarily demand (for self-consistency) that $\bar{X}$ be along the curve that passes through $X$. As such, for an arbitrary parameter $\Delta$, we define the trajectory to be such that the tangent vector satisfies

$$
\dot{\Gamma}^{A}(\varepsilon)=\Pi^{A B}(\varepsilon)\left[\nabla_{B} H(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon)\right]_{\bar{X} \rightarrow \Upsilon_{\Delta}(X)}
$$

The expression on the right-hand side is a coincidence limit of the bitensorial expression in brackets, which is defined simply by taking the limit $\bar{X} \rightarrow \Upsilon_{\Delta}(X)$ after taking the derivative. Coincidence limits arise naturally in the discussion of bitensors; see, for example, the description in [13]. Note that this is a slight generalization of the expressions presented in [49-51], where it was assumed that $\Delta=0$; we adopt this more general approach as it will simplify the discussion later in Sec. IV.

At this point, we now explicitly restrict to the firstorder formulation; here, it is the case that everything which we need to know about the evolution of the perturbed trajectory $\Gamma$ is given by $\delta \Gamma^{A}$, the tangent to the congruence $\Gamma(\tau ; \varepsilon)$ where $\tau$ is fixed and $\varepsilon$ varies. That is, for any scalar field $f$,

$$
\left.\delta \Gamma^{A} \nabla_{A} f\right|_{\Gamma(\tau)} \equiv\left.\frac{\partial f[\Gamma(\tau ; \varepsilon)]}{\partial \varepsilon}\right|_{\varepsilon=0}
$$

As we describe more explicitly in Sec. III below, let us also define the variation of any tensor $\boldsymbol{Q}$ by

$$
\left.\delta \boldsymbol{Q} \equiv \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{Q}}{\partial \varepsilon}\right|_{\varepsilon=0}
$$

As shown in Sec. II.B. 2 of [41], the following evolution equation for $\delta \Gamma^{A}$ follows from Eq. (2.9), using the notation of the pseudo-Hamiltonian formalism (which was only implicit in [41]):

$$
\left.\mathcal{L}_{\bar{\Gamma}} \delta \Gamma^{A}=\Pi^{A B}\left[\nabla_{B} \delta H(X, \bar{X})\right]_{\bar{X} \rightarrow \Upsilon_{\Delta}(X)}\right.
$$

[^1]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ Note that, while they sound somewhat exotic, the idea of pseudoHamiltonian systems is far from new (see the discussion and references in [52]). For an example from the gravitational radiation literature, the Burke-Thorne potential for the leading-order post-Newtonian radiation-reaction force (see the discussion in Chapter 12 of [24]),

    $$
    \Phi^{R B}(x)=\frac{1}{5} x_{i} x_{j} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{5} I^{(i j)}}{\mathrm{d} t^{5}}
    $$

    can be thought of as the potential energy part of a pseudoHamiltonian: the quadrupole moment $I^{i j}$ depends on the trajectory of the object undergoing radiation reaction, which is kept fixed when $\Phi^{R B}$ is differentiated with respect to $x^{i}$ to find the force \{to see this, compare Eqs. (12.198) and (12.204) of [24] $\}$.

[^1]:    ${ }^{4}$ In order to describe self-force in the so-called "self-consistent formalism" [15, 53], one would need to instead consider the Hamiltonian flow map associated with the exact motion in the definition of the pseudo-Hamiltonian, which we would denote $\Upsilon_{\Delta}(\varepsilon)$. However, since we are computing the first-order self-force, the self-consistent formalism is not necessary, and so we just use the background Hamiltonian flow map.

where we have also explicitly assumed that (as in [41])

$$
\delta \Pi^{A B}=0
$$

That is, the Poisson bracket structure is fixed ${ }^{5}$ as a function of $\varepsilon$. Note that this is a "gauge-dependent" statement: it only holds in a certain class of coordinates [for example, those in Eq. (2.41)], and if one performs an $\varepsilon$ dependent coordinate transformation (depending, for example, on the metric perturbation), then Eq. (2.12) will necessarily change. It is for this reason that we work in coordinates related to those in Eq. (2.41) by fieldindependent coordinate transformations.

In order to solve Eq. (2.12), one needs to integrate vectors on phase space. On a general manifold, one does not have a means of adding and subtracting vectors at different points, which is necessary in order to have a welldefined notion of integration along a curve. On the spacetime manifold, one can typically use parallel transport, that is, the parallel propagator bitensor $g^{a^{\prime}}{ }_{a}$, but there is no natural notion of parallel transport on phase space. However, on phase space there still exists a bitensor that allows for transport for vectors along $\Gamma$, the Hamilton propagator [41]. This is a bitensor defined along $\Gamma$ by the following equation: for any scalar field $f$, and any pair of points $X=\Gamma(\tau)$ and $X^{\prime}=\Gamma\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)$, the Hamilton propagator $\Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{A}$ satisfies

$$
\nabla_{A}\left(f \circ \Upsilon_{\tau^{\prime}-\tau}\right)=\Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{A} \nabla_{A^{\prime}} f
$$

In other words, the Hamilton propagator is the pushforward of the Hamiltonian flow map $\Upsilon_{\Delta},{ }^{6}$ and is a bitensor that is a one-form at $\Gamma(\tau)$ and a vector at $\Gamma(\tau+\Delta){ }^{7}$

In coordinates, the chain rule implies that

$$
\Upsilon^{\mathrm{B}}{ }_{\mathcal{Z}}\left(\tau^{\prime}, \tau\right)=\frac{\partial X^{\mathrm{B}}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)}{\partial X^{\mathcal{Z}}(\tau)}
$$

where $X^{\mathrm{B}}(\tau)$ denotes the coordinates of $\Gamma(\tau)$. That is, in order to compute this bitensor, and so integrate Eq. (2.12), one needs to solve for the background trajectory in terms of initial data. We perform this explicit calculation in the relevant cases in Secs. VA and VB.

[^0]In addition to Eqs. (2.14) and (2.15), the Hamilton propagator has a few very convenient properties. First, as it is created from a map from the manifold into itself, it has a natural composition property:

$$
\Upsilon^{A}{ }_{A^{\prime}} \Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{A^{\prime \prime}}=\Upsilon^{A}{ }_{A^{\prime \prime}}, \quad \Upsilon^{A}{ }_{A^{\prime}} \Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{B}=\delta^{A}{ }_{B}
$$

Next, consider the Lie derivative with respect to $\dot{\Gamma}^{A}$ of some tensor $T^{\mathscr{A}}$, where $\mathscr{A}$ is some composite index. For such composite indices, there exists a Hamilton propagator $\Upsilon^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}}$ which uses $\Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{A}$ for mapping contravariant indices at $X$ to $X^{\prime}$, and $\Upsilon^{A}{ }_{A^{\prime}}$ for covariant indices. The Lie derivative is then defined by \{compare to Eq. (C.2.1) of $[45]\}$

$$
\mathscr{L}_{\dot{\Gamma}} T^{\mathscr{A}} \equiv \lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda}\left(\Upsilon^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} T^{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}}\right)\left.\right|_{X^{\prime}=\Gamma(\tau+\lambda)}
$$

As such, from Eq. (2.16) it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Upsilon^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} \mathscr{L}_{\dot{\Gamma}^{\prime}} T^{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} & =\left.\lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda}\left(\Upsilon^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime \prime}} T^{\mathscr{A}^{\prime \prime}}\right)\right|_{X^{\prime \prime}=\Gamma\left(\tau^{\prime}+\lambda\right)} \\
& =\left.\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \tau^{\prime}}\left(\Upsilon^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} T^{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}}\right)\right|_{X^{\prime}=\Gamma\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

by the chain rule. As such, if the Lie derivative of $T^{\mathscr{A}}$ is known at all points along $\Gamma$, one can potentially integrate this equation to solve for $T^{\mathscr{A}}$.

We now use the Hamilton propagator to define a notion of an average rate of change of $\delta \Gamma^{A}$ : first, define

$$
\delta \dot{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right) \equiv \Upsilon^{A}{ }_{A^{\prime}} \mathscr{L}_{\dot{\Gamma}^{\prime}} \delta \Gamma^{A^{\prime}}
$$

where $X^{\prime}=\Gamma\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)$, and then define, for any bitensor $f^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)$ that is a scalar at $\tau^{\prime}$, the average

$$
\left\langle f^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}} \equiv \lim _{\Delta \tau \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\Delta \tau} \int_{\tau_{-}}^{\tau_{+}} \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} f^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)
$$

where $\tau_{ \pm} \equiv \tau \pm \Delta \tau / 2$. From this, we have that the average rate of change of $\delta \Gamma^{A}$ is given by

$$
\left\langle\delta \dot{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\Pi^{A B}\left\langle\left[\nabla_{B} \delta H\left(\Upsilon_{\tau^{\prime}-\tau}(X), \bar{X}\right)\right]_{\bar{X} \rightarrow X}\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}
$$

where we have used Eq. (2.14), together with Eq. (2.18) and the fact that

$$
\mathscr{L}_{\dot{\Gamma}} \Pi^{A B}=0
$$

which follows from the Jacobi identity (see Proposition 10.4.1 of [48]). In principle, one can then use Eq. (2.18) to show that

$$
\left\langle\delta \dot{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}} \equiv \lim _{\Delta \tau \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\Upsilon_{A^{\prime}}^{A} \delta \Gamma^{A^{\prime}}-\Upsilon_{A^{\prime \prime}}^{A} \delta \Gamma^{A^{\prime \prime}}}{\Delta \tau}
$$

where the points $X^{\prime}$ and $X^{\prime \prime}$ in the numerator on the right-hand side are at $\tau \pm \Delta \tau / 2$, respectively. This equation provides an alternative way of thinking about this

## B. Linear-in-spin motion

In this section, we review the motion of spinning test bodies, to linear order in the spin. The background motion is described in terms of three quantities: the fourvelocity $\dot{\gamma}^{a}$ (which, for concreteness, we assume is normalized using the metric $g_{a b}$ to have length -1 ), the momentum $p_{a}$, and the spin $S^{a b}$. These three quantities obey the Mathisson-Papapetrou-Dixon (MPD) equations $[2-4]$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\gamma}^{b} \nabla_{b} p_{a} & =-\frac{1}{2} R_{a b c d} \dot{\gamma}^{b} S^{c d}+F_{a} \\
\dot{\gamma}^{c} \nabla_{c} S^{a b} & =2 p_{c} g^{c[a} \dot{\gamma}^{b]}+N^{a b}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $F^{a}$ and $N^{a b}$ are (respectively) forces and torques that are due to the structure of the body, arising from higher multipoles (such as the quadrupole moment, for example). In this paper, we will neglect the presence of these higher multipoles, applying the pole-dipole approximation; due to the generic presence of a spin-induced quadrupole, this requires us to also neglect quantities which are second-order in spin, for consistency.

Equations (2.24) do not provide a complete set of equations for the 13 unknowns $\dot{\gamma}^{a}, p_{a}$, and $S^{a b}$; these are only 10 equations, and so we must supplement them with an additional choice in order to fix the location of the worldline. Such a choice is called a spin-supplementary condition, and we will adopt the Tulczyjew-Dixon condition $[4,55]$ for the remainder of this paper: ${ }^{8}$

$$
d^{a} \equiv S^{a b} p_{b}=0
$$

This condition is a constraint that the mass-dipole moment, as measured in the rest frame of $p^{a}$, vanishes. Under this spin-supplementary condition, the MPD equations take on the following form, to linear order in spin:

[^0]$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\gamma}^{a} & =\frac{1}{m} g^{a b} p_{b}+O\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{2}\right) \\
\dot{\gamma}^{b} \nabla_{b} p_{a} & =-\frac{1}{2} R_{a b c d} \dot{\gamma}^{b} S^{c d} \\
\dot{\gamma}^{c} \nabla_{c} S^{a b} & =O\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
m^{2} \equiv-g^{a b} p_{a} p_{b}+O\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{2}\right)
$$

by the normalization of the four-velocity. For the remainder of this paper, we will implicitly neglect any $O\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{2}\right)$ terms.

Now, one thing to note about the motion described by Eqs. (2.26) is that it is not, in fact, equivalent to Eqs. (2.24) with the Tulczyjew-Dixon condition satisfied: instead, one can only prove from Eq. (2.26) that

$$
\dot{\gamma}^{b} \nabla_{b} d^{a}=0
$$

Instead of considering the "true", restricted phase space for spinning bodies in this paper, we will be considering Eq. (2.26) as given, and then apply $d^{a}=0$ as an initial condition, which by Eq. (2.28) implies that the Tulczyjew-Dixon condition holds for all time. The Hamiltonian which we consider below is therefore for a "fictitious" problem that does not correspond to the physical motion, and the physical motion is only recovered when the initial data are such that Eq. (2.25) holds. This will be sufficient for our purposes, and (as we will show below in Sec. III B) it is necessary for our results to hold in the form they do.

We now discuss the Hamiltonian formulation of this background motion, starting with the case where the spin vanishes. This is exactly geodesic motion, given by

$$
\dot{\gamma}^{b} \nabla_{b} \dot{\gamma}^{a}=0
$$

As one can straightforwardly show (see, for example, [41]), this equation follows from Hamilton's equations, where the coordinates on the (now 8-dimensional) phase-space are given by

$$
X^{\mathrm{R}}=\binom{x^{\alpha}}{p_{\alpha}}
$$

the Poisson bivector $\Pi^{A B}$ 's non-zero components are determined by

$$
\left\{x^{\alpha}, p_{\beta}\right\}=\delta^{\alpha}{ }_{\beta}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is given by

$$
H(X)=-m(X)
$$

where we consider the mass $m$, as defined by Eq. (2.27), explicitly as a function on phase space. Hamilton's equations also show that

$$
\dot{\gamma}^{a}=\frac{1}{m} g^{a b} p_{b}
$$


[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ As we are explicitly excluding the null case, we are free to ignore the known pathologies of this spin-supplementary condition in this case (see, for example, the discussion in $[56,57]$ and pg. 70 of $[58]$ ).

directly enforcing the normalization of $\dot{\gamma}^{a}$.
For the spinning case, the situation is more subtle. First, suppose that one uses

$$
X^{\mathrm{B}}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
x^{\alpha} \\
p_{\alpha} \\
S^{\alpha \beta}
\end{array}\right)
$$

as coordinates on the 14-dimensional phase space. If one uses the Poisson bivector given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\{x^{\alpha}, p_{\beta}\right\} & =\delta^{\alpha}{ }_{\beta} \\
\left\{p_{\alpha}, p_{\beta}\right\} & =-\frac{1}{2} R_{\alpha \beta \gamma \delta} S^{\gamma \delta} \\
\left\{S^{\alpha \beta}, p_{\gamma}\right\} & =2 \Gamma^{[\alpha}{ }_{\gamma \delta} S^{\beta] \delta} \\
\left\{S^{\alpha \beta}, S^{\gamma \delta}\right\} & =2\left(g^{\alpha[\delta} S^{\gamma] \beta}-g^{\beta[\delta} S^{\gamma] \alpha}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(a natural choice appearing throughout the literature [59-61]), then the Hamiltonian for the MPD equations with the Tulczy̨ew-Dixon spin supplementary condition is still given by Eq. (2.32) (see [62] for an extensive discussion of the relationship between the choice of spinsupplementary condition and Hamiltonian). This means that $\Pi^{A B}$ is metric-dependent, and as we will see below, this implies that $\delta \Pi^{A B} \neq 0$, which significantly complicates the analysis.

Instead, following [60,63], we define better coordinates for this problem by first introducing the orthonormal tetrad $\boldsymbol{e}_{\hat{\alpha}}$, defined by

$$
g_{a b}\left(e_{\hat{\alpha}}\right)^{a}\left(e_{\hat{\beta}}\right)^{b}=\eta_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}
$$

Here, we denote tetrad indices using hatted Greek letters, to distinguish them from spacetime coordinate indices. The corresponding dual tetrad $\boldsymbol{e}^{\hat{\alpha}}$ is defined by

$$
\left(e^{\hat{\alpha}}\right)_{a}\left(e_{\hat{\beta}}\right)^{a}=\delta^{\hat{\alpha}}{ }_{\hat{\beta}}, \quad\left(e_{\hat{\alpha}}\right)^{a}\left(e^{\hat{\alpha}}\right)_{b}=\delta^{a}{ }_{b}
$$

(which are equivalent), from which it follows that

$$
g^{a b}\left(e^{\hat{\alpha}}\right)_{a}\left(e^{\hat{\beta}}\right)_{b}=\eta^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}
$$

Moreover, we consider the connection one-form $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}$ defined by

$$
\left(\omega_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}\right)_{a}=g_{b c}\left(e_{\hat{\alpha}}\right)^{b} \nabla_{a}\left(e_{\hat{\beta}}\right)^{c}
$$

Using these quantities, we define

$$
\hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}} \equiv\left(e^{\hat{\alpha}}\right)_{a}\left(e^{\hat{\beta}}\right)_{b} S^{a b}, \quad \pi_{a} \equiv p_{a}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\omega_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}\right)_{a} \hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}
$$

and use the following coordinates on phase space:

$$
X^{\mathrm{R}}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
x^{\alpha} \\
\pi_{\alpha} \\
\hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}$ is antisymmetric.

Since, as mentioned above, $H$ in the original coordinates is given by Eq. (2.32), it follows that in these good coordinates it is given by the same equation, but with $m$ defined as a function of $\pi_{\alpha}$ and $\hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}$ through a variable which we call $p_{a}(X)$ :

$$
H(X)=-\sqrt{-g^{a b} p_{a}(X) p_{b}(X)}
$$

where we have defined $p_{a}(X)$ by

$$
p_{a}(X) \equiv \pi_{a}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\omega_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}\right)_{a} \hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}
$$

What has changed is that the non-zero components of the Poisson bivector are now determined by $[60,63]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\{x^{\alpha}, \pi_{\beta}\right\} & =\delta^{\alpha}{ }_{\beta} \\
\left\{\hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}, \hat{S}^{\hat{\gamma} \hat{\delta}}\right\} & =2\left(\eta^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}} \hat{S}^{\hat{\gamma} \hat{\beta}}-\eta^{\hat{\beta} \hat{\delta}} \hat{S}^{\hat{\gamma} \hat{\alpha}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that now $\Pi^{A B}$ no longer depends explicitly on $g_{a b}$.
With the background motion now fully presented, we can now consider the motion of the spinning particle under the gravitational self-force. As shown in [64-66], for a non-spinning particle, there exists an "effective" metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}[\gamma ; \varepsilon]$ (defined in Sec. III B below) such that

- the worldline $\gamma$ and the variable $p_{a}$ are now functions of $\varepsilon$,
- the metric $g_{a b}$ is replaced with the effective metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}[\gamma ; \varepsilon]$, and
- all quantities which are constructed from the metric ( $\nabla_{a}$ and $\dot{\gamma}^{a}$ due to its normalization) are all replaced with versions $\left(\bar{\nabla}_{a}[\gamma ; \varepsilon] \text { and } \dot{\gamma}^{a}[\gamma ; \varepsilon]\right)$ which are all constructed from the effective metric.

This means that we can describe non-spinning self-force motion using the following pseudo-Hamiltonian:

$$
H(X, \bar{X})=-\bar{m}(X, \bar{X})
$$

where $\bar{m}$ is defined in terms of the effective metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}$, considered as a function of some arbitrary point in phase space through the trajectory (defined using the background Hamiltonian) that passes through $\bar{X}$. That is, $\bar{m}$ is defined as in Eq. (2.27), but with

$$
\tilde{g}_{a b}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon) \equiv \tilde{g}_{a b}[\pi \circ \Upsilon .(\bar{X}) ; \varepsilon]
$$

replacing $g_{a b}$, where $\Upsilon .(\bar{X})$ abstractly denotes the curve determined by considering $\Upsilon_{\Delta}(\bar{X})$ as a function of $\Delta$.

For the case of spinning body motion, we assume ${ }^{9}$ that a similar prescription applies: in addition to the points described above for non-spinning motion, the equations of motion are the same as those described above in Eq. (2.26), but with the following modifications:

- $S^{a b}$ is also a function of $\varepsilon$, and
- the Riemann tensor $R^{a}{ }_{b c d}$ is replaced by $\bar{R}^{a}{ }_{b c d}[\gamma ; \varepsilon]$, which is constructed from the effective metric.
From this, the pseudo-Hamiltonian is given by modifying Eq. (2.42) as in Eq. (2.45):

$$
H(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon) \equiv-\sqrt{-\bar{g}^{a b}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon) \bar{p}_{a}(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon) \bar{p}_{b}(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon)}
$$

where $\bar{p}_{a}$ is defined analogously to how it is defined in Eq. (2.43), except by using a $\left(\bar{e}_{\dot{\alpha}}\right)^{a}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon)$ and $\bar{\omega}_{\dot{\alpha} \dot{\beta}}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon)$ that are defined from $\bar{g}_{a b}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon)$ and its compatible covariant derivative, instead of $g_{a b}$, using Eqs. (2.36) and (2.39), respectively. Note that $\left(e^{\dot{\alpha}}\right)_{a}$ does not appear in Eq. (2.43), and so $\left(\bar{e}^{\dot{\alpha}}\right)_{a}(\bar{X} ; \varepsilon)$ does not arise in this equation. As mentioned above, since the components of $\Pi^{A B}$ in these coordinates are independent of $g_{a b}$, there is no modification of $\Pi^{A B}$ in this gauge to an analogous $\bar{\Pi}^{A B}$.

## III. FIELD EQUATIONS

Next, we review the perturbative field equations in the problem of spinning, self-forced motion. We start by describing the notation which we will use in the rest of this section. Suppose that one has a tensor field $\boldsymbol{Q}[\boldsymbol{\Phi}]$ which is a functional of some other tensor field $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$, whose indices we collectively denote with the composite index $\mathscr{A}$. For example, one could consider the case where $\Phi_{a b}$ is the metric $g_{a b}$, in which case $\mathscr{A}$ represents $a b$. The functional dependence of $\boldsymbol{Q}$ on $\boldsymbol{\Phi}$ is, in general, nonlinear, although we will assume that it is still local.

Now, suppose that $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$ is a function of a single parameter $\lambda$. It then follows that one can define, from $\boldsymbol{Q}$, a local, linear functional $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ by writing

$$
\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}(\lambda)\left\{\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{\Phi}}{\partial \lambda}\right\} \equiv \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{Q}}{\partial \lambda}
$$

[^0]where we have dropped the functional dependence on $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$ on both sides, but we have explicitly included the dependence on $\lambda$. When we set $\lambda=0$, we write the partial derivative as a variation $\delta$ [as in Eq. (2.11)] and omit the dependence on $\lambda$ from $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}$ :

$$
\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\} \equiv \delta \boldsymbol{Q}
$$

We use curly braces in these equations to indicate the fact that $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ (or $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}$ ) is a local, linear functional of $\partial \Phi_{\mathscr{A}} / \partial \lambda$ (or $\delta \Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$ ). Occasionally, it is useful to consider local, linear functionals of a single argument as operators, which can be accomplished by giving them an additional index (dual to that of their argument), and in an index-free context we denote their action on their argument with a $\cdot$. That is, for such a functional $\mathcal{Q}$ which we evaluate with some argument $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$, we can interchangeably write

$$
\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}\} \equiv \boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}^{\mathscr{A}} \Phi_{\mathscr{A}} \equiv \boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }} \cdot \boldsymbol{\Phi}
$$

While $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ reflects the linear dependence of $\boldsymbol{Q}$ on $\boldsymbol{\Phi}$, the quadratic dependence of $\boldsymbol{Q}$ on $\boldsymbol{\Phi}$ will also be occasionally be relevant. This dependence can be recovered from the remaining dependence of $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ on $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$, which we have neglected in the equations above. This can be seen as follows: for any local functional $\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}(\lambda)$, which depends nonlinearly on $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}(\lambda)$ and linearly on some $\phi_{\mathscr{A}}(\lambda)$, we take a derivative with respect to $\lambda$ to define $\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ :

$$
\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}^{\prime}(\lambda)\left\{\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{\Phi}}{\partial \lambda}, \boldsymbol{\phi}(\lambda)\right\} \equiv \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}(\lambda)\{\boldsymbol{\phi}(\lambda)\}}{\partial \lambda}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}(\lambda)\left\{\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{\phi}}{\partial \lambda}\right\}
$$

Unlike above, we explicitly eliminate any derivatives of the arguments using the second term on the right-hand side; in other words, we are taking the derivative with respect to $\lambda$, with the argument of $\mathcal{Q}$ fixed. In the case where we set $\lambda=0$, this becomes

$$
\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}^{\prime}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}, \boldsymbol{\phi}\}=\delta \boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}\{\boldsymbol{\phi}\}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal { Q }}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\phi}\}
$$

We can now use this procedure to define $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime \prime}$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime \prime}\left\{\delta_{1} \boldsymbol{\Phi}, \delta_{2} \boldsymbol{\Phi}\right\} & \equiv \delta_{1} \boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\left\{\delta_{2} \boldsymbol{\Phi}\right\}-\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\left\{\delta_{1} \delta_{2} \boldsymbol{\Phi}\right\} \\
& =\delta_{1} \delta_{2} \boldsymbol{Q}-\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\left\{\delta_{1} \delta_{2} \boldsymbol{\Phi}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second line makes it apparent that $\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime \prime}$, which is essentially the "quadratic part" of $\boldsymbol{Q}$, is symmetric in its two arguments. It follows from these definitions that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{Q}(\lambda)= & \boldsymbol{Q}+\lambda \boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\}+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime}\left\{\delta^{2} \boldsymbol{\Phi}\right\}+\boldsymbol{Q}^{\prime \prime}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}, \delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\}\right) \\
& +O\left(\lambda^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

With this notation established, in the remainder of this section we first describe a local, bilinear current $\omega$, the symplectic current, which is conserved when the source-free, perturbative equations of motion are satisfied. We then turn to the discussion of the perturbative

## A. Symplectic currents

As it is central for the definition of our flux-balance law, we start by introducing a current, the symplectic current, which will be conserved when the vacuum equations of motion are satisfied. The conservation of such a current in vacuum regions is crucial for allowing fluxbalance laws to be promoted from being local to the particle to truly global flux-balance laws involving quantities at the boundaries of spacetime.

The definition of the symplectic current begins with considering the Lagrangian formulation of the theory in question; while in this paper we only consider general relativity, the discussion here can be generalized to a theory for an arbitrary field $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$. Unlike usual treatments of the Lagrangian formulation, we adopt the approach of $[69,70]$ in working entirely locally: instead of using an action, we consider only the variation of the integrand which appears in the action, which is naturally given by a Lagrangian four-form $\boldsymbol{L}$. This description has two advantages over using the usual action approach: first, one does not need to introduce a compensating boundary term in theories such as general relativity where the Lagrangian depends on second derivatives of the field. Second, the boundary term arising in the variation, which is typically neglected at various points in the action approach, appears far more prominently.

Upon variation of the Lagrangian four-form, one finds that (subject to certain technical assumptions, such as covariance [69])

$$
\delta \boldsymbol{L}=\boldsymbol{E}^{\mathscr{A}} \delta \Phi_{\mathscr{A}}+\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\}
$$

Here, the tensor-valued four-form $\boldsymbol{E}^{\mathscr{A}}$ vanishes when the equations of motion are satisfied, and the three-form $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ is the integrand of the usual boundary term which arises when varying an action.

The three-form $\boldsymbol{\theta}$, often called the symplectic potential [69], can then be used to define the symplectic current $\omega$ as an antisymmetric, multilinear functional:

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{1}, \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\} \equiv \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{1}, \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\}-(1 \longleftrightarrow 2)
$$

By taking a second variation of Eq. (3.8), one can show that

$$
\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\omega}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{1}, \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\}=\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{1}\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{\mathscr{A}}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\}-(1 \longleftrightarrow 2)
$$

That is, it is conserved when the linearized equations of motion hold. This is the key property of the symplectic
current which we will use throughout the remainder of this paper.

Note, however, that there is an issue with using the symplectic product in order to define a flux at infinity: it is a bilinear, antisymmetric current, which requires that we have two different field perturbations on the background spacetime, each satisfying the equations of motion, in order to construct a conserved current. On the other hand, physically relevant fluxes are typically quadratic in the field. However, if we were to have an operator, which we denote by $\mathcal{D}_{\mathscr{A}}{ }^{\mathscr{B}}$, which maps the space of solutions to the vacuum equations of motion to itself, we could resolve this issue by using such a map to define a quadratic current from a single perturbation [70]. Such an operator is called a symmetry operator [71].

Explicitly, a symmetry operator is an operator $\mathcal{D}_{\mathscr{A}}{ }^{\mathscr{B}}$ satisfying

$$
\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{\mathscr{A}}\{\boldsymbol{\mathcal { D } \cdot} \delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\}=\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{B}}\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{\mathscr{B}}\{\delta \boldsymbol{\Phi}\}
$$

for some other operator $\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{B}}$. In this sense, symmetry operators "commute with (the perturbed) equations of motion, up to equations of motion". For any field theory, one can always construct a symmetry operator from a vector field $\xi^{a}$ as follows: consider the fields $\boldsymbol{\psi}$ from which the equations of motion $\boldsymbol{E}^{\mathscr{A}}$ are constructed. In the case of gravity, this is simply the (dynamical) field $g_{a b}$, but for theories with non-dynamical fields (such as Klein-Gordon theory or electromagnetism on a fixed background spacetime) $\boldsymbol{\psi}$ would include both $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}$ and the non-dynamical fields (such as the metric). If this vector field satisfies $\pounds_{\xi} \boldsymbol{\psi}=0$, then $\pounds_{\xi}$ will be a symmetry operator. For gravity, or for theories with a fixed metric that are linearized off of a background where $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}=0$, this is simply the condition that $\pounds_{\xi} g_{a b}=0$, or that $\xi^{a}$ generates isometries. In addition, however, for specific theories and backgrounds, there exist symmetry operators not associated with isometries

- in the presence of a background, rank-two Killing tensor, for Klein-Gordon theory [72];
- in the presence of a background, rank-two KillingYano tensor for Dirac (and Weyl) fermions [73, 74] and electromagnetism [74-76]; and
- for linearized gravity on the Kerr spacetime [7779], due to it being Petrov type D, and therefore possessing a rank-two Killing-Yano tensor [39].
In this paper, we will, however, not be concerned with any of these symmetry operators, and instead focus on a symmetry operator introduced in [41] which arises only in the case of solutions to the self-force equations of motion given in Sec. III B below.

Inserting any symmetry operator into the symplectic current, we can define a new current which satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\omega}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{1}, \boldsymbol{\mathcal { D } \cdot} \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\}= & \Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{1} \widetilde{\mathcal{D}}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{B}}\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{\mathscr{B}}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{2}\right\} \\
& -\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{\mathscr{A}}\left\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}^{1}\right\} \mathcal{D}_{\mathscr{A}}{ }^{\mathscr{B}} \Phi_{\mathscr{B}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, this current is now no longer antisymmetric in $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{1}$ and $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{2}$, and can therefore be used to define a quadratic current from a single perturbation $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{1}=\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{2}$. In the case where $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{1}$ and $\Phi_{\mathscr{A}}^{2}$ are both vacuum solutions to the linearized field equations, it then follows that the right-hand side of Eq. (3.12) vanishes, and so the current is conserved.

For concreteness, we now give the expression for this symplectic current in the relevant theory, general relativity. The Einstein-Hilbert Lagrangian is given by ${ }^{10}$

$$
\boldsymbol{L}=-R \boldsymbol{\epsilon}
$$

which implies that

$$
\boldsymbol{E}^{a b}=G^{a b} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}
$$

Moreover, the symplectic potential is given by

$$
\theta_{a b c}\{\boldsymbol{h}\}=-2\left(C^{\prime}\right)^{[d}{ }_{e f}\{\boldsymbol{h}\} g^{e] f} \epsilon_{d a b c}
$$

where $\left(C^{\prime}\right)^{a}{ }_{b c}\{\boldsymbol{h}\}$ is the linearized connection coefficient constructed from the metric perturbation $h_{a b}$. The symplectic current is then given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{a b c}\left\{\boldsymbol{h}^{1}, \boldsymbol{h}^{2}\right\}=2\left[\left(C^{\prime}\right)^{[d}{ }_{e f}\left\{\boldsymbol{h}^{2}\right\} P^{e] g f h} h_{g h}^{1}\right. \\
& \left.\quad-(1 \longleftrightarrow 2)\right] \epsilon_{d a b c}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
P^{e g f h} \equiv g^{(e] g} g^{[f] h}-\frac{1}{2} g^{e f} g^{g h}
$$

is the trace-reversal operator.

## B. Self-force

As promised above in Sec. II B, we now determine the effective metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}$ which appears in the equations of motion. First, consider the retarded solution $h_{a b}$ that is sourced by the worldline $\gamma$ by the following partial differential equation:

$$
\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{a b}\{\boldsymbol{h}[\gamma]\}=8 \pi \boldsymbol{T}^{a b}[\gamma]
$$

where, from Eq. (3.14) (and the fact that we are in a vacuum background spacetime), $\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{a b}$ is a differential-form version of the linearized Einstein operator and $\boldsymbol{T}^{a b}[\gamma]$ is a distributional source that is given below in Eq. (3.27). In particular, $h_{a b}$ is a vacuum solution off of $\gamma$. In a convex normal neighborhood of $\gamma$, one can split the retarded

[^0]field $h_{a b}$ into two fields, the singular field $h_{a b}^{S}$, which is the part which is not a vacuum solution, and in fact blows up, on $\gamma$ :

$$
\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{a b}\left\{\boldsymbol{h}^{S}[\gamma]\right\}=8 \pi \boldsymbol{T}^{a b}[\gamma]
$$

and the regular field $h_{a b}^{R}$, which remains a smooth vacuum solution, even on $\gamma$ :

$$
\left(\boldsymbol{E}^{\prime}\right)^{a b}\left\{\boldsymbol{h}^{R}[\gamma]\right\}=0
$$

The effective metric is then defined by

$$
\tilde{g}_{a b}[\gamma ; \varepsilon] \equiv g_{a b}+\varepsilon h_{a b}^{R}[\gamma]
$$

While it is unimportant for the discussion in this paper, one can operationally compute these fields as follows: first, up to a given order in distance from the source, $h_{a b}^{S}$ has a known analytic form (given, for example, in [67]). After solving for the full retarded solution $h_{a b}$, one can then simply subtract off $h_{a b}^{S}$ in order to obtain $h_{a b}^{R}$. Typically, this is only done at some truncated order in distance to the particle, but at sufficiently high order that the value of $h_{a b}^{R}$ and its first derivative can be recovered exactly. At second order, this discussion becomes more complicated; see for example [80].

Finally, we need to describe the differential-form version of the stress-energy tensor on the right-hand side of Eqs. (3.18) and (3.19). In terms of the variables $p_{a}$ and $S^{a b}$, it is given by [67]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{T}^{a b}[\gamma]=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} g^{a^{\prime} d^{\prime}} p_{d^{\prime}}}{m\left(X^{\prime}\right)}\left(g^{b^{\prime} c^{\prime}} p_{c^{\prime}} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{a b}{ }_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}\right. \\
& \left.+S^{b^{\prime} c^{\prime}} \nabla_{c} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{[a b] c}{ }_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime} c^{\prime}}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x^{\prime} \equiv \gamma\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)$ and $\delta_{a b c d}{ }^{\mathscr{E}}{ }_{\mathscr{E}^{\prime}}$ is a bitensor-valued fourform distribution (note that the four-form indices are at $x$, the same point as the first set of indices). This distribution is defined by the following property: when integrated against a tensor $f_{\mathscr{A}}$ over some volume $V$, one finds

$$
\int_{V} f_{\mathscr{A}} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
f_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} & x^{\prime} \in V \\
0 & x^{\prime} \notin V
\end{array}\right.
$$

for any collections of indices $\mathscr{A}$ and $\mathscr{B}$. As such, this stress-energy tensor is supported entirely on $\gamma$. Moreover, the distribution $\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}}$ satisfies the property that

$$
\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\mathscr{A} \mathscr{B}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime} \mathscr{B}^{\prime}}=\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\mathscr{B} \mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{B}^{\prime} \mathscr{A}^{\prime}}
$$

Further, note that, upon taking a derivative $\nabla_{b^{\prime}}$ of Eq. (3.23), we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{V} f_{\mathscr{A}} \nabla_{b^{\prime}} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{\mathscr{A}}{ }_{\mathscr{A}^{\prime}} & =\int_{V}\left(\nabla_{b} f_{\mathscr{A}}\right) \boldsymbol{\delta}^{b \mathscr{A}}{ }_{b^{\prime} \mathscr{A}^{\prime}} \\
& =-\int_{V} f_{\mathscr{A}} \nabla_{b} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{b \mathscr{A}}{ }_{b^{\prime} \mathscr{A}^{\prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We adopt the choice in Eq. (3.13) such that Eq. (3.14) takes a particularly simple form.

and so

$$
\nabla_{b^{\prime}} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{c d}{ }_{c d^{\prime}}=-\nabla_{b} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{b c d}{ }_{b^{\prime} c d^{\prime}}
$$

This implies that we can write

$$
\boldsymbol{T}^{a b}[\gamma]=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} g^{a^{\prime} d^{\prime}} p_{d^{\prime}}}{m\left(\bar{X}^{\prime}\right)}\left(g^{b^{\prime} c^{\prime}} p_{c^{\prime}}-S^{b^{\prime} c^{\prime}} \nabla_{c^{\prime}}\right) \boldsymbol{\delta}^{(a b)}{ }_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}

Finally, we discuss a very useful property of the selfforce in both the non-spinning and linear-in-spin cases, which we call Hamiltonian alignment. This is a relationship between the pseudo-Hamiltonian $H(\varepsilon)$ and the stress-energy tensor which appears in the self-force equations of motion in Eq. (3.27). To introduce some notation, we define, for any tensor $\boldsymbol{Q}(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon)$ which depends on $\bar{X}$ and $\varepsilon$ through $\varepsilon h_{a b}^{R}(\bar{X})$, the tensors

$$
(\partial \boldsymbol{Q})^{c_{1} \cdots c_{n} a b}(X) \equiv\left.\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{Q}(X, \bar{X} ; \varepsilon)}{\partial \nabla_{c_{1}} \cdots \nabla_{c_{n}} h_{a b}^{R}(\bar{X})}\right|_{\boldsymbol{h}^{R}(\bar{X})=0}
$$

The Hamiltonian alignment property is that, for some constant $C_{g}$,

$$
\boldsymbol{T}^{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}[\pi \circ \Upsilon_{.}(X)]=C_{g} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime \prime} \mathcal{T}^{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}\left(X, \tau^{\prime \prime}\right)
$$

where, defining $X^{\prime \prime}=\Upsilon_{\tau^{\prime \prime}-\tau}(X)$ and $x^{\prime \prime}=\pi\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{T}^{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}\left(X, \tau^{\prime \prime}\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\partial H)^{c_{1}^{\prime \prime} \cdots c_{n}^{\prime \prime} a^{\prime \prime} b^{\prime \prime}}\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right) \\
\times \nabla_{c_{1}^{\prime \prime}} \cdots \nabla_{c_{n}^{\prime \prime}} \boldsymbol{\delta}^{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}{ }_{a^{\prime \prime} b^{\prime \prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that, while such a relationship is plausible from the generalized equivalence principle and the fact that both the stress-energy tensor and the background Hamiltonian must come from an action principle, we have not been able to prove this result more generally. A version of this relationship also holds for the scalar field theory considered in [41], which (although not emphasized there) was key in the derivation of the flux-balance law in that paper.

In the case of a point particle, first note that

$$
(\partial m)^{a b}(X)=\frac{g^{a c} g^{b d} p_{c} p_{d}}{2 m(X)}
$$

Using Eq. (3.30), and comparing with Eq. (3.27), we find that the Hamiltonian alignment condition holds, with $C_{g}=-1 / 2$. There are no terms in Eq. (3.30) beyond $n=0$, since the pseudo-Hamiltonian in this case does not depend upon derivatives of the metric perturbation. To linear order in spin, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}

& \left.+\left(\partial \omega_{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}\right)_{d}{ }^{a b} \hat{S}^{\hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

However, from Eq. (2.36), we find that

$$
\left(\partial e_{\hat{\alpha}}\right)^{a b c}=-\frac{1}{2} g^{a(b}\left(e_{\hat{\alpha}}\right)^{c)}
$$

where

reflects the dependence of the connection coefficients on $\nabla_{b} h^{R}{ }_{c d}$. The first term on the second line of this equation cancels with the term on the second line of Eq. (3.37), and so we find that

By comparing Eqs. (3.35) and (3.40) to Eq. (3.27) and (3.30), we see that, even in the linear-in-spin case, the Hamiltonian alignment condition holds, with $C_{g}=$ $-1 / 2$. We do not need to go beyond $n=1$ in Eq. (3.28) because there are no terms in the pseudo-Hamiltonian which depend on more than one derivative of the metric perturbation.

It is at this point that we can comment on the reason why it is necessary for us to work on the 14-dimensional, "fictitious" phase space where the spin-supplementary condition $d^{a}=0$ is not required to hold. An alternative approach would have been to use the Hamiltonian in Eq. (2.42) in coordinates where one has already restricted to the surface where $d^{a}=0$. However, in writing these coordinates in terms of the well-behaved coordinates in Eq. (2.41), one needs to explicitly introduce factors of the metric, which in passing to the self-force pseudoHamiltonian would introduce an additional dependence on $h_{a b}^{R}(\bar{X})$. This would spoil the Hamiltonian alignment condition, and so for simplicity we work on the larger, 14-dimensional phase space.

## IV. GENERAL FLUX-BALANCE LAWS

We now discuss our approach to flux-balance laws in general spacetimes. First, as discussed above, any metric perturbation $h_{a b}^{-}$in this problem (for example, the full retarded field $h_{a b}$ ), depends on a worldline $\gamma$ [for example, via Eq. (3.18)]. As such, as in Eq. (2.46), it can be considered as a function of a point $X$ which lies along a trajectory $\Gamma$ through phase space at some fixed time $\tau$, via the Hamiltonian flow map $\Upsilon$ :

$$
h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{-}(X) \equiv h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{-}[\pi \circ \Upsilon .(X)]
$$

As in [41], we then consider the operation given by taking a derivative with respect to $X$, which (as before) we denote by $\nabla_{A}$. Note that derivatives of $h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{-}(X)$ with respect to $X$ and $x^{\prime}$ act independently since, considered as a bitensor at $X$ and $x^{\prime}, h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{-}(X)$ does not impose any relationship through its definition (unlike, say, $\Upsilon^{A^{\prime}}{ }_{A}$ ). As such, $\nabla_{A}$ and $\nabla_{a^{\prime}}$ commute, and moreover $\nabla_{A} g_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}=0$ (the background metric is not a function of $X$ ), so $\nabla_{A}$ is a symmetry operator.

Using this symmetry operator, we can define a flux integral over some hypersurface, which we generically denote by $\Sigma(\tau, \Delta \tau)$. We assume that this hypersurface is a tube surrounding the worldline $\gamma$, with boundaries which we denote by $\partial \Sigma_{ \pm}$. These surfaces $\partial \Sigma_{ \pm}$are also the boundaries of hypersurfaces $\Sigma_{ \pm}$which intersect $\gamma$ at $\gamma\left(\tau_{ \pm}\right)$, where $\tau \pm \equiv \tau \pm \Delta \tau / 2$. The two hypersurfaces we will be integrating our fluxes over will consist of an outer boundary $\mathcal{B}(\tau, \Delta \tau)$, which we will later assume can be extended down to the event horizon $\mathscr{H}$ and out to null infinity $\mathscr{I}$, and a worldtube $\mathcal{W}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)$ of some proper radius $r$. Note that $\mathcal{W}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)$ needs to be within the convex normal neighborhood of $\gamma$. As a visual aid, see Fig. 1.

## A. Local flux-balance laws

We first consider local flux-balance laws at the worldtube $\mathcal{W}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)$ around the particle. We start with the fact that the chain rule, together with Eqs. (2.11) and (3.28), implies that

$$
\delta H\left(X^{\prime}, \bar{X}\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\partial H)^{c_{1}^{\prime} \cdots c_{n}^{\prime} a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}\left(X^{\prime}\right) \nabla_{c_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots \nabla_{c_{n}^{\prime}} h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}(\bar{X})
$$

Inserting Eq. (4.5) into Eq. (2.21), we find that

$$
\left\langle\delta \hat{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\Pi^{A B}\left\langle\left[\nabla_{B} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\partial H)^{c_{1}^{\prime} \cdots c_{n}^{\prime} a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}\left\{\Upsilon_{\tau^{\prime}-\tau}(X)\right\} \nabla_{c_{1}^{\prime}} \cdots \nabla_{c_{n}^{\prime}} h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}(\bar{X})\right]_{\bar{X} \rightarrow X}\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}
$$

We then replace the factors of $h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}$ with integrals over delta functions, so that, by using Eq. (3.30),

$$
\left\langle\delta \hat{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\Pi^{A B}\left\langle\left[\nabla_{B} \int_{\mathcal{V}(\tau, \infty ; r)} h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}(\bar{X}) \boldsymbol{\mathcal { T }}{ }^{a^{\prime \prime} b^{\prime \prime}}\left(X, \tau^{\prime}\right)\right]_{\bar{X} \rightarrow X}\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}
$$

where we have used the fact that the inner covariant derivatives acting on $h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}(\bar{X})$ in Eq. (4.6) are now applied to the delta functions, and where $\mathcal{V}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)$ is the volume containing the worldline $\gamma$ such that its boundary is the worldtube:

$$
\partial \mathcal{V}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)=\mathcal{W}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r) \cup \mathcal{W}_{+}(r) \cup \mathcal{W}_{-}(r)
$$

[and similarly $\partial \mathcal{V}(\tau, \infty ; r)=\mathcal{W}(\tau, \infty ; r)$ ]. What this has done is "factor" the dependence on $\bar{X}$ onto something which is now clearly is independent of $X$, and so (after interchanging the order of the integrals) we can simply set $\bar{X}=X$. In interchanging the order of the integrals, we can also switch the bounds on the $\tau^{\prime}$ integral from $\tau_{ \pm}$ to $\pm \infty$ and from the volume $\mathcal{V}(\tau, \infty ; r)$ to $\mathcal{V}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)$ :

$$
\left\langle\delta \hat{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\lim _{\Delta \tau \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\Pi^{A B}}{\Delta \tau} \int_{\mathcal{V}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)} h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R}(X)
$$

So far, the discussion has to be $\int_{\tau}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}}{\mathrm{d} \tau} \boldsymbol{\mathcal { T }}{ }^{a^{\prime \prime} b^{\prime \prime}}\left(\boldsymbol{X}, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ agnostic. However, in the case where the Hamiltongies

$$
\left\langle\delta \hat{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\lim _{\Delta \tau \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\Pi^{A B}}{C_{g} \Delta \tau} \int_{\mathcal{V}(\tau, \Delta \tau ; r)} h_{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}^{R} \nabla_{B} \boldsymbol{T}^{a^{\prime} b^{\prime}}
$$

where (for brevity) we drop the dependence on $X$ on the right-hand side. We now use Stokes' theorem and Eq. (3.12), which implies that

$$
\left\langle\delta \hat{\Gamma}^{A}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{\tau^{\prime}}=\Pi^{A B} \mathcal{F}_{B}^{\mathcal{W}(r)}\left\{\boldsymbol{h}^{R}, \boldsymbol{h}^{S}\right\}
$$

This is the same sort of flux-balance law which was originally proven in [41]: as it is constructed from the regular and singular fields, it is only applicable near the worldline.

Now, by bilinearity, there will be a contribution to the flux term in Eq. (4.3) coming from the same term that appears on the right-hand side of Eq. (4.11), except with $h_{a b}^{R}$ and $h_{a b}^{S}$ switched. We now compute this contribution. First, note that Eq. (3.12) implies that
